Award.AwardTitle: Building Excellence in Undergraduate STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description
The project is supporting The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) to organize and run Principal Investigator (PI) meetings in 2013 and in 2015 for the Transforming Undergraduate Education in STEM (TUES) program (and its predecessor, the Course, Curriculum, and Laboratory Instruction (CCLI) program). The objective of the conferences is to provide opportunities for TUES/CCLI PIs to share methods and strategies for preparing a diverse undergraduate student population to enter the scientific workforce and to participate as citizens in a technological society. The overall outcome of these conferences is for TUES PIs to identify collaborators, strategies, and actions that they and others can use to strengthen the design, development, and implementation of promising project approaches to transform undergraduate STEM education. The conferences include plenary lectures, poster sessions, interactive workshop discussions on topics of interest to those leading TUES projects, and opportunities to network with other faculty and educational leaders engaged in improving undergraduate STEM education.

Broader Significance
Each conference includes more than 500 TUES/CCLI PIs and 50 other participants, including publishers and staff of professional societies, foundations, and business. All TUES/CCLI PIs selected to participate in the conferences must present a small group session or a poster. Other non-NSF participants are expected to disseminate information about strategies and concepts. To ensure diversity among the topics and participants, selection is taking into account discipline, type of project, type of institution, race/ethnicity, gender, disability, and geographic location. The on-site project evaluation is capturing actions that participants intend to take immediately after each conference. An online follow-up survey is capturing actions that participants are taking no later than three months after each conference. Products to be developed include conference programs with printed abstracts and glossy post-conference publications with case studies of exemplary TUES projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2011 to 2018, the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) cosponsored a series of  conferences, online forums, working meetings and webinars with the National Science Foundation (NSF) Division of Undergraduate Education (DUE) to provide faculty and other NSF awardees with an opportunity to: (a) learn about and share innovative ideas for transforming undergraduate science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education; (b) implement innovative STEM undergraduate education ideas, as appropriate; (c) spread the use of innovative STEM undergraduate education ideas to their colleagues; and (d) make new connections and create collaborations.

Project activities with links to online and print resources, included the

(A) 2012 working meeting and publication, Describing & Measuring Undergraduate Teaching Practices (http://ccliconference.org/measuring-teaching-practices/).

(B) January 2013 Transforming Undergraduate Education conference, Building a Community to Transform Undergraduate STEM Education (http://ccliconference.org/2013-tuesccli-pi-conference/) and the implementation of the 2013 NSF Principal Investigator (PI) Forums. The conference included plenary and poster sessions, workshops, small group PI-led discussion sessions, and NSF Program Director (PD) led sessions. The PI Forums were intended to foster post-conference collaboration among PIs who were interested in continuing collaborations with other PIs. (http://ccliconference.org/pi-forum/).

(C) September 2014 NSF Engineering Education Meeting. This meeting brought together faculty and staff with awards through NSF Division of Engineering Education and Centers and DUE to promote the exchange of ideas, best practices, and recent advances in their work. This meeting focused on social inequality in engineering and hopefully provided new perspectives and opened new dialogue on productive ways forward for increasing diversity in engineering education and the profession (http://www.nsf.gov/div/index.jsp?org=EEC).

(D) April 2016 symposium, Envisioning the Future of Undergraduate STEM Education (EnFUSE): Research and Practice, in Washington, DC (http://www.enfusestem.org/). The symposium included plenary and poster sessions, workshops, paper presentations, small group PI-led discussion sessions, and "speed dating" with NSF PDs and PD-led small group sessions.

(E) July 2017 meeting with 37 participants to discuss the current state of reform within the biological sciences as a result of the Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education initiative which began in 2006. A report on the meeting was prepared by the facilitator, Ann Austin, Professor of Education and Associate Dean of Education Research, University of Michigan and the AAAS staff.  http://visionandchange.org/about-vc-unpacking-a-movement-2018/

(F) May 2018 meeting of 62 research and education faculty and staff across the STEM disciplines to capture a snapshot of the current state of research-based reform in undergraduate STEM instruction and to identify levers to move forward in the next decade within six clusters of disciplines, including: (a) biological sciences; (b) chemistry and biochemistry; (c) engineering and computer science; (d) geosciences; (e) mathematical sciences; and (f) physics and astronomy. The agenda and pre-conference papers for this meeting are online. https://sites.google.com/view/levers-for-change/home

The number of combined meeting attendees for these events included nearly1500 faculty and staff from over 350 colleges and universities and 28 professional societies and educational organizations.

Other resources and products developed include the:

***online 2013 TUES abstract locator with 392 conference abstracts. In some cases, posters are included (http://ccliconference.org/search-2013/).

***online EnFUSE abstract locator and app with 485 symposium abstracts. In some cases, posters and papers are included (http://www.enfusestem.org/abstracts/).

***printed conference and symposium programs (http://ccliconference.org/files/2013/01/2013-Tues-Conference-Program.pdf and http://www.enfusestem.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/EnFuseSymposiumProgramBook_2016.pdf).

In addition, AAAS and NSF staff co-hosted 26 Improving Undergraduate Education (IUSE) proposal preparation webinars in 2013, 2014, 2015, and 2016. Overall, 3,692 faculty and staff from 778 colleges and universities and other institutions registered for the IUSE webinars.

From Feb 1, 2010 to Dec 16, 2018 - the TUES-CCLI website had 20,143 users and 120,276 page views.

From September 2016 to Dec 16, 2018 - the EnFUSE website had 3,816 users and 5,169 page views.

The Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education website includes 5 reports from 2009 to 2018, chronicling changes and impact (http://visionandchange.org/). Over 10,000 print reports have been distributed.

According to Google Analytics, since June 2011, the Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology website has had 82,813 users and 230,678 page views.

The various conferences, symposia, on-line PI forums, working meetings, webinars and related products provide STEM college and university faculty, staff, and others with an opportunity to learn about:

***dissemination and project management;

***materials development for use in courses and labs;

***teaching strategies;

***personnel development (faculty, post-docs, graduate student, etc.);

***research and assessment;

***technology-based education;

***outreach, including community college partnerships.

***evaluation strategies;

***other NSF funding opportunities;

***preparing NSF reports: present and future; and 

***project sustainability.

From data collected via internal and external evaluation, many undergraduate STEM faculty and other educators are using and sharing resources and strategies developed by NSF undergraduate education awardees and others in their classes and labs. Also, as indicated by the 6 STEM discipline-based papers commissioned in 2018, there appears to be an increased use of active learning strategies in undergraduate STEM classes and labs across the country.
